Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description:
Even in victory, George Karl was an angry coach.
Milwaukee held off the Indiana Pacers 106-102 on Tuesday night, but Karl said selfish play by Sam Cassell and Ray Allen nearly cost the Bucks a game they led by a lot.
article.headline: O'Neal out at least one game with knee injury
article.linkText: Pacers lose O'Neal; Bucks hold on for win
article.story:
INDIANAPOLIS (AP) -- Even in victory, George Karl was an angry coach. Milwaukee held off the Indiana Pacers 106-102 on Tuesday night, but Karl said selfish play by Sam Cassell and Ray Allen nearly cost the Bucks a game they led by 15 points early in the fourth quarter. "Our leadership from Sam and Ray has been awful. They are being selfish," Karl said. "They don't execute. They don't pass the ball." Tim Thomas scored 25 points and Cassell and Allen each had 23, but the Pacers held the Bucks scoreless for 4 minutes and nearly pulled out the win on a night Jermaine O'Neal left with a first-quarter injury and Reggie Miller was ejected in the fourth. Karl said Cassell and Allen took ill-advised shots down the stretch, allowing the Pacers to close the gap. Cassell wasn't buying Karl's explanation. "We won the game," he said. "I don't want to hear that. We won the game." Jonathan Bender, who had 14 points, hit a 3-pointer to make it a nine-point game. Jalen Rose hit a baseline jumper off an inbounds pass to cut it to 97-94 with 2:11 remaining. The Bucks scored the next three points on free throws before Rose hit a 3 to make it 102-99 with 24.8 seconds to go and no timeouts left for Indiana. Thomas converted two free throws for Milwaukee before Rose hit another 3 from the top of the key. Milwaukee held a 104-102 lead when Rose drove the lane and was fouled by Thomas with 3.2 seconds to go. But Rose's first free throw rattled in and out, and the Bucks grabbed the rebound off the ensuing intentional miss to clinch the win. Rose has seen his production decrease over the past two months and sat out five fourth quarters in a recent seven-game stretch. The Pacers' leading scorer the past two seasons has taken a seat as the offense has shifted inside to Jermaine O'Neal and Al Harrington. Rose, an 83 percent free-throw shooter, said there was no excuse for his miss. "I knock down my free throws for the most part," Rose said. "They call those a shooter's miss. I call that 'the end of the game choker's miss.' I've got to find a way to knock it down. I should have knocked it down." Rose led the Pacers with 26 points. and Miller added 24 before he was ejected. Jeff Foster had 10 points and 13 rebounds and Jamaal Tinsley added 11 points and 12 assists. Michael Redd had 15 points and Anthony Mason 14 for the Bucks, who won their fourth straight. The Pacers scored a season-low 10 points in the second quarter, missing 12 of 16 shots. O'Neal was carried off the court after he sprained his left knee by landing awkwardly after he jumped for a rebound with 4:47 left in the second quarter. He immediately grabbed his knee and couldn't stand up. O'Neal will not travel with the team for Wednesday's night game at Milwaukee. "He's a huge part of what we do," Pacers coach Isiah Thomas said. "The way the league is, you take a monster off the team, you're not the same team." The Bucks went on a 12-2 run following the injury for a 59-44 halftime lead. Milwaukee stretched the lead to 20 in the third. Miller and Bender combined for seven points in an 11-1 run that brought it to 85-75 at the end of the third. The Pacers, though, scored only two points in the first five minutes of the fourth. Allen fell after getting tangled with Miller, who was coming off a screen. Miller was called for a personal foul, argued with the official, then was hit with a technical. He was substituted for, jawed some more with from the bench and was hit with another technical. Game notes
The Pacers had scored 12 points in a quarter against New York and the Los Angeles Clippers. ... O'Neal entered the game averaging 18.6 points, 10.7 rebounds and had 87 blocked shots -- all team highs. O'Neal missed three games earlier this year with a bruised lower back. ... Mason was called for a technical foul in the third quarter. ... The Bucks beat the Pacers 115-95 in their first meeting this season. ... Even without O'Neal, the Pacers held a 49-44 rebounding edge.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
